uses:
Primary Use: Fat loss, insulin sensitivity, and muscle preservation

Mechanism: Inhibits NNMT → increases NAD⁺ → enhances metabolism, mitochondrial function, and AMPK activity

Clinical Target: Obesity, metabolic syndrome, sarcopenia
side_effects: Headache · mild jitteriness · queasy stomach
contraindication: Uncontrolled high BP · Severe anxiety / bipolar disorder · Advanced liver or kidney disease · You already take an MAOI antidepressant

uses:
Primary Use: Fat burning (lipolysis) without affecting blood sugar or GH levels

Mechanism: Fragment of hGH (176–191) → targets adipose tissue to promote lipolysis

Clinical Target: Obesity, localized fat reduction
side_effects: Headache · light dizziness · mild belly upset
contraindication: Any active cancer · Uncontrolled diabetes · Serious heart failure

uses:
Primary Use: Tissue regeneration, gut repair, injury recovery

Mechanism: Stimulates angiogenesis via VEGF modulation. Enhances fibroblast migration and collagen production. Modulates nitric oxide, dopamine, and serotonin for tissue protection

Clinical Target: Tendon and ligament injuries. Leaky gut, ulcers, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Muscle, nerve, and joint healing. Post-surgical recovery
side_effects: Sore or red spot if injected · mild nausea · tiredness
contraindication: Active or recent cancer · Bleeding/clotting disorder

uses:
Primary Use: Tissue regeneration, gut repair, injury recovery

Mechanism: Stimulates angiogenesis via VEGF modulation. Enhances fibroblast migration and collagen production. Modulates nitric oxide, dopamine, and serotonin for tissue protection

Clinical Target: Tendon and ligament injuries. Leaky gut, ulcers, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Muscle, nerve, and joint healing. Post-surgical recovery
side_effects: Sore or red spot if injected · mild nausea · tiredness
contraindication:
Active or recent cancer · Bleeding/clotting disorder

Autoimmune flare that’s already raging

uses:
Primary Use: Gut inflammation control, immune modulation

Mechanism: BPC-157: Promotes angiogenesis and epithelial repair. KPV: Suppresses pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6) by binding melanocortin-1 receptor (MC1R) and inhibiting NF-κB signaling

Clinical Target: Ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease, IBS. Systemic inflammation with gut involvement. Leaky gut with immune activation. Inflammatory skin and mucosal conditions (via systemic immune modulation)
side_effects: Sore or red spot if injected · mild nausea · tiredness  · occasional facial flushing
contraindication:
Active or recent cancer · Bleeding/clotting disorder

Autoimmune flare that’s already raging

uses:
Primary Use: Growth hormone stimulation, anti-aging, recovery, fat loss

Mechanism: CJC-1295 (GHRH analog) + Ipamorelin (Ghrelin mimetic) → increase GH/IGF-1

Clinical Target: GH deficiency, aging, sleep, body composition
side_effects: Water retention → puffy fingers, tingling, wrist ache · bigger appetite · warm flushing
contraindication: Active malignancy · Proliferative diabetic eye disease · Known pituitary tumour · Untreated severe sleep apnoea

uses:
Primary Use: Cognitive enhancement, neurogenesis, Alzheimer's support

Mechanism: Angiotensin IV derivative → promotes synaptogenesis and BDNF potentiation

Clinical Target: Cognitive decline, TBI, neurodegeneration, learning/memory support
side_effects: Headache · vivid dreams · water retension
contraindication: Active cancer · Recurrent fainting or very low blood-pressure episodes

uses:
Primary Use: Systemic tissue repair, wound healing, inflammation control

Mechanism: Regulates gene expression for tissue regeneration and anti-inflammation

Clinical Target: Healing, anti-aging, fibrosis, organ protection
side_effects: Coppery/metal taste right after the shot · itchy or red skin at site · brief light-headed feeling
contraindication: Active/suspected cancer or copper/metal metabolism disorders (Wilson's disease) and allergies to metals.

uses:
Primary Use: Immune modulation, inflammation control, chronic pain management

Mechanism: At low doses (typically 0.5–4.5 mg), naltrexone temporarily blocks opioid receptors → rebound increase in endogenous endorphins (met-enkephalin, β-endorphin). Modulates immune response by inhibiting TLR4 (Toll-like receptor 4) on microglia and immune cells → reduces pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β)

Clinical Target: Autoimmune diseases: Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, multiple sclerosis (MS), psoriasis, Crohn’s disease. Chronic pain syndromes: Fibromyalgia, complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS), neuropathic pain. Neuroinflammation: ME/CFS, long COVID, depression with inflammatory component

Cancer support: Adjunct therapy (via immune enhancement and modulation of tumor microenvironment)
side_effects: Vivid dreams · trouble falling asleep (first week) · mild stomach cramp
contraindication:
Narcotics/Alcohol use (LDN blocks opioid receptors). Need one full week off prior to prescribing LDN

Acute hepatitis or decompensated liver disease

uses:
Primary Use: Mitochondrial function, cognitive enhancement, anti-aging

Mechanism: Acts as an electron donor in mitochondrial complex IV, improves ATP production

Clinical Target: Cognitive decline, neurodegeneration, chronic fatigue, Long COVID
side_effects: Blue-green pee & tongue · nausea · headache
contraindication: G-6-PD deficiency · You take an SSRI/SNRI (serotonin-syndrome risk) · Severe kidney disease

uses:
Primary Use: Metabolic regulation, mitochondrial function, weight loss

Mechanism: Mitochondrial-derived peptide → activates AMPK, improves insulin sensitivity

Clinical Target: Obesity, insulin resistance, age-related metabolic decline
side_effects: Red or sore injection spot · mild nausea · fatigue
contraindication: Active cancer · Unstable heart rhythm · End-stage kidney disease

uses:
Primary Use: Energy, DNA repair, anti-aging, neurological health

Mechanism: Restores NAD⁺ levels → activates sirtuins, PARPs, and mitochondrial function

Clinical Target: Fatigue, neurodegeneration, addiction, aging
side_effects: Flushing or warm rush if pushed fast · tight chest or throat · headache
contraindication: Severely low blood-pressure states · Known NAD allergy · Recurrent phlebitis

uses:
Primary Use: Cognitive enhancement, memory, neuroprotection

Mechanism: Nicotinic receptor agonist → enhances cholinergic signaling

Clinical Target: Alzheimer's support, ADHD, focus, cognitive fatigue
side_effects: Mouth or throat burn · hiccups · nausea
contraindication: Recent heart attack or stroke · Uncontrolled HTN · Serious arrhythmia

uses:
Primary Use: Sexual arousal and libido enhancement

Mechanism: Melanocortin-4 receptor agonist → CNS-mediated libido modulation

Clinical Target: Erectile dysfunction, hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD)
side_effects: Nausea · warm facial flushing · headache · darkened gums/skin patches
contraindication: Uncontrolled high BP · Significant heart disease · Personal / family history of melanoma

uses:
Primary Use: Sexual arousal and libido enhancement

Mechanism: Melanocortin-4 receptor agonist → CNS-mediated libido modulation

Clinical Target: Erectile dysfunction, hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD)
side_effects: Stuffy nose · same (usually milder) systemic effects
contraindication: Uncontrolled high BP · Significant heart disease · Personal / family history of melanoma

side_effects: Nausea · diarrhea or constipation · dizziness when standing
contraindication: Personal/family medullary thyroid cancer or MEN-2 · Past pancreatitis · Severe gastroparesis · Symptomatic gall-stones · breastfeeding

uses:
Primary Use: Anxiolytic, cognitive enhancement, mood stabilization

Mechanism: Synthetic tuftsin analog → modulates GABA and serotonin systems

Clinical Target: Anxiety, depression, ADHD, stress
side_effects: Mild calming or, rarely, pep · slight nose burn · headache
contraindication: Acute psychosis or mania · Active, severe sinus infection

side_effects: Nausea · constipation or diarrhea · belly pain
contraindication: MTC or MEN-2 · Pancreatitis history · Severe diabetic eye disease needing treatment · Severe gastroparesis · breastfeeding

uses:
Primary Use: Neuroprotection, cognitive support, stress modulation

Mechanism: ACTH fragment analog → boosts BDNF, regulates neurotransmission

Clinical Target: Stroke recovery, anxiety, cognition, neuroinflammation
side_effects: Bitter drip · nose irritation · mild headache
contraindication: Uncontrolled hypertension · Active nasal/sinus infection

uses:
Primary Use: Stimulates natural GH release, anti-aging, body composition

Mechanism: GHRH analog → stimulates pituitary to release GH

Clinical Target: GH deficiency, fatigue, recovery, muscle mass
side_effects: Water retention (swelling, numbness) · warm flushing · headache
contraindication: Active cancer · Pituitary tumour · Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

uses:
Primary Use: Metabolic enhancement, longevity, insulin sensitization

Mechanism: Direct AMPK agonist → mimics exercise effects and improves glucose uptake

Clinical Target: Obesity, metabolic syndrome, aging, mitochondrial disorders

Note: If not pairing with a GLP1, patients will notice inches lost vs lbs lost. Great for body recomposition, building more musles & lose fat. This is why it's great to pair with a GLP1 to maximize results
side_effects: Restlessness · faster heart rate (in mice)
contraindication: Serious liver disease · Clinically significant arrhythmia (human safety unknown)

uses:
Primary Use: Tissue regeneration, soft tissue healing

Mechanism: Promotes cell migration, angiogenesis, and actin polymerization → enhances wound healing and reduces fibrosis

Clinical Target: Chronic injuries, post-surgical recovery, inflammation
side_effects: Fatigue · mild chills · light dizziness
contraindication: Active malignancy · Major bleeding disorder or you’re on full-dose anticoagulants

uses:
Primary Use: Reduce visceral adiposity and enhance GH output

Mechanism: GHRH analog → increases endogenous GH and reduces visceral fat

Clinical Target: HIV-related lipodystrophy, abdominal obesity, aging-related fat gain
side_effects: Water retention (swelling, joint ache, carpal tunnel) · injection-site itch
contraindication: Active cancer · Pituitary tumour · Proliferative retinopathy · Uncontrolled diabetes

uses:
Primary Use: Appetite suppression and fat loss

Mechanism: Triple monoamine reuptake inhibitor (serotonin, dopamine, norepinephrine) → increases energy and suppresses hunger

Clinical Target: Obesity, weight management, potentially ADHD
side_effects: Dry mouth · trouble sleeping · faster pulse
contraindication:
Uncontrolled hypertension · Serious heart disease / arrhythmia · Severe anxiety or psychosis
- SSRIs (Excluding Wellbutrin)

uses:
Primary Use: Immune system modulation and antiviral defense

Mechanism: Enhances T-cell function, promotes immune homeostasis

Clinical Target: Chronic viral infections, immune deficiency, cancer adjunct, inflammation
side_effects: Low-grade fever · tiredness · sore/red spot
contraindication: Generally none absolute; most clinics still pause during active cancer unless oncologist approves

uses:
Primary Use: Immune system modulation and antiviral defense

Mechanism: Enhances T-cell function, promotes immune homeostasis

Clinical Target: Chronic viral infections, immune deficiency, cancer adjunct, inflammation
side_effects: Runny or burning nose
contraindication:
Autoimmune disease (controversial; may modulate T-cell response)

Organ transplant recipients (immune activation risk)

Pregnancy or breastfeeding

side_effects: Nausea · diarrhea/constipation · injection bump · shedding hair during rapid weight-loss
contraindication: MTC or MEN-2 · Prior pancreatitis · Severe gut-motility disorder · Symptomatic gall-stones · breastfeeding

uses:
Primary Use: Restore physiological testosterone levels, improve vitality, libido, muscle mass, and cognitive function

Mechanism: Supplementation with bioidentical testosterone (usually cypionate, enanthate, or transdermal). Binds androgen receptors → regulates gene transcription related to anabolic, sexual, and cognitive functions. May include adjuncts (e.g., HCG or anastrozole) to maintain fertility and control estrogen conversion

Clinical Target: Hypogonadism (primary or secondary). Andropause (age-related testosterone decline). Low libido, erectile dysfunction. Sarcopenia, insulin resistance, cognitive decline, low mood"
side_effects: Sore butt/leg after the shot · oily skin or new acne · thicker facial/body hair (or faster scalp thinning) · feeling “amped-up” or more irritable · bigger appetite and a bit of water retention → puffy ankles or rings feel tight · higher sex-drive · smaller testes / lower sperm count over time
contraindication:
Prostate or male breast cancer · PSA in diagnostic gray-zone until cleared · Hematocrit > 54 % · Untreated severe sleep apnoea · Uncontrolled heart failure · Severe polycythaemia · Desire to maintain fertility (unless using HCG/FSH) - Blood thinner (automatic denial), under the age of 25

- Testing contraindication: no oral & intercourse 2 days prior to getting blood drawn, could possibly elevate PSA levels

uses:
Primary Use: Restore physiological testosterone levels, improve vitality, libido, muscle mass, and cognitive function

Mechanism: Supplementation with bioidentical testosterone (usually cypionate, enanthate, or transdermal). Binds androgen receptors → regulates gene transcription related to anabolic, sexual, and cognitive functions. May include adjuncts (e.g., HCG or anastrozole) to maintain fertility and control estrogen conversion

Clinical Target: Hypogonadism (primary or secondary). Andropause (age-related testosterone decline). Low libido, erectile dysfunction. Sarcopenia, insulin resistance, cognitive decline, low mood"
side_effects: Same body-wide effects as above, but peaks are smoother; add: skin irritation or rash where you rub it · risk of rubbing off on a partner, kids, or pets
contraindication:
Prostate or male breast cancer · PSA in diagnostic gray-zone until cleared · Hematocrit > 54 % · Untreated severe sleep apnoea · Uncontrolled heart failure · Severe polycythaemia · Desire to maintain fertility (unless using HCG/FSH) - Blood thinner (automatic denial), under the age of 25

- Testing contraindication: no oral & intercourse 2 days prior to getting blood drawn, could possibly elevate PSA levels

uses:
Primary Use: Hormonal balance during perimenopause, menopause, or surgical menopause; alleviates symptoms and supports longevity

Mechanism: Supplementation with bioidentical estradiol, progesterone, and sometimes testosterone. Binds to estrogen/progesterone receptors → modulates transcription for vascular, neurological, bone, and reproductive health. Often delivered as transdermal estradiol + oral or transvaginal progesterone (to protect endometrium)

Clinical Target: Menopausal symptoms (hot flashes, night sweats, mood instability). Osteopenia/osteoporosis. Vaginal dryness, sexual dysfunction. Sleep disorders, cognitive fog. HPA axis dysregulation and mood disorders
side_effects: Breast tenderness/swelling · bloating or “puffy” hands/feet (water retention) · mild nausea · mood swings or crying spells · spotting between periods (first 1–3 mo) · headache · sore injection site
contraindication: Breast cancer or estrogen-dependent tumour · History of DVT/PE, stroke, or MI · Active liver disease · Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding · Porphyria cutanea tarda - Blood thinner (automatic denial),  under the age of 25

uses:
Primary Use: Hormonal balance during perimenopause, menopause, or surgical menopause; alleviates symptoms and supports longevity

Mechanism: Supplementation with bioidentical estradiol, progesterone, and sometimes testosterone. Binds to estrogen/progesterone receptors → modulates transcription for vascular, neurological, bone, and reproductive health. Often delivered as transdermal estradiol + oral or transvaginal progesterone (to protect endometrium)

Clinical Target: Menopausal symptoms (hot flashes, night sweats, mood instability). Osteopenia/osteoporosis. Vaginal dryness, sexual dysfunction. Sleep disorders, cognitive fog. HPA axis dysregulation and mood disorders
side_effects: Same body-wide effects as the injection but gentler rise/fall
contraindication: add: itchy or red skin where applied · transfer risk to partner/children

uses:
Primary Use: Hormonal balance during perimenopause, menopause, or surgical menopause; alleviates symptoms and supports longevity

Mechanism: Supplementation with bioidentical estradiol, progesterone, and sometimes testosterone. Binds to estrogen/progesterone receptors → modulates transcription for vascular, neurological, bone, and reproductive health. Often delivered as transdermal estradiol + oral or transvaginal progesterone (to protect endometrium)

Clinical Target: Menopausal symptoms (hot flashes, night sweats, mood instability). Osteopenia/osteoporosis. Vaginal dryness, sexual dysfunction. Sleep disorders, cognitive fog. HPA axis dysregulation and mood disorders
side_effects: Breast tenderness and bloating · metallic or bitter taste for a minute · sore mouth spot if you always park it in the same place · hormone levels can bounce around from dose to dose
contraindication: Breast cancer or estrogen-dependent tumour · History of DVT/PE, stroke, or MI · Active liver disease · Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding · Porphyria cutanea tarda · severe oral mucosal disease or chronic dental issues that prevent absorption, under the age of 25

uses:
Primary Use: for short-term weight loss in individuals with obesity (BMI ≥30) or overweight with comorbidities (BMI ≥27) 

Mechanism: it works by stimulating norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin release in the hypothalamus, leading to appetite suppression and a reduction in food intake.
side_effects: insomnia, dry mouth, increased heart rate, elevated blood pressure, restlessness, irritability, headache, and constipation.
contraindication: Cardiovascular disease (e.g., arrhythmias, coronary artery disease), uncontrolled hypertension, hyperthyroidism, glaucoma, a history of drug or stimulant abuse, or those currently using monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), SSRIs

uses:
Primary Use: Stimulate natural testosterone production in males with secondary hypogonadism, support spermatogenesis in fertility protocols, and trigger ovulation in women undergoing fertility treatments; it mimics luteinizing hormone (LH) by binding LH receptors in the Leydig cells of the testes or ovarian theca cells, leading to increased testosterone or ovulation, depending on the context.

Clinical Target: Prevention of testicular atrophy during testosterone replacement therapy (TRT). Maintaining fertility in men using anabolic steroids or androgens. Assisting in weight loss/hormonal regulation in certain obesity-related protocols (off-label)
side_effects:
Injection site pain or irritation

Water retention / bloating

Mood swings or irritability

Gynecomastia (due to estrogen conversion)

Headache or fatigue

Increased acne or oily skin (androgenic effects)
contraindication:
Known or suspected hormone-sensitive cancers (e.g., prostate or breast cancer in men, estrogen-dependent tumors in women)

Precocious puberty

Undiagnosed uterine or genital bleeding

Known hypersensitivity to HCG or its components

Active thromboembolic disorders

Pregnancy (for off-label uses)

uses:
Primary Use: Accelerate soft tissue healing, reduce inflammation, enhance recovery from musculoskeletal injuries, and protect against chronic joint/tendon degeneration

Mechanism:

BPC-157: Derived from gastric juice; promotes angiogenesis, fibroblast migration, collagen synthesis, and nitric oxide–mediated blood flow to injured tissues

TB-500 (Thymosin Beta-4): Increases cell migration, actin polymerization, and tissue regeneration while reducing inflammatory cytokines

Synergistic action improves tendon, ligament, and muscle repair while enhancing overall recovery rate

Clinical Target: Acute and chronic tendon, ligament, or muscle injuries; joint degeneration; post-surgical healing; repetitive strain injuries; sports injury recovery
side_effects: Mild injection site irritation · transient fatigue · dizziness · mild headache
contraindication: Active or recent cancer · Bleeding/clotting disorder · Uncontrolled infection

uses:
Primary Use: Promote systemic healing and anti-aging effects with enhanced skin repair, hair growth, and tissue regeneration

Mechanism:

BPC-157 & TB-500: Tissue repair and anti-inflammatory actions as above

GHK-Cu (Copper Peptide): Stimulates collagen and glycosaminoglycan synthesis in skin, supports hair follicle stem cells, improves skin elasticity, and promotes angiogenesis

Combined systemic repair with cosmetic rejuvenation effects (skin, hair, nails)

Clinical Target: Skin aging, hair thinning, wound healing, surgical recovery, scar reduction, joint/tendon injuries, and overall regenerative support
side_effects: Mild injection site irritation · temporary skin redness · mild headache · transient metallic taste
contraindication: Active or recent cancer · Bleeding/clotting disorder · Wilson’s disease (copper overload) · Uncontrolled infection

uses:
Primary Use: Reduce systemic and gut inflammation, promote musculoskeletal and skin repair, and restore epithelial barrier function

Mechanism:

BPC-157: Enhances vascular supply, collagen repair, and tendon/gut healing

KPV (α-MSH fragment): Potent anti-inflammatory peptide, suppresses NF-κB signaling, reduces pro-inflammatory cytokines in gut and systemic tissues

TB-500: Improves cellular migration, tissue regeneration, and reduces fibrosis

GHK-Cu: Supports collagen remodeling, skin regeneration, and angiogenesis

Multi-pathway action for inflammation control, tissue regeneration, and aesthetic rejuvenation

Clinical Target: Inflammatory bowel disease, leaky gut, systemic inflammatory syndromes, chronic musculoskeletal injury, post-surgical healing, skin/hair regeneration
side_effects: Mild injection site irritation · loose stools · transient fatigue · mild headache
contraindication: Active or recent cancer · Bleeding/clotting disorder · Wilson’s disease (copper overload) · Severe immunosuppression · Uncontrolled infection
